Requirements: The CSD program is a non-competitive program, meaning there are no extra application materials needed to declare the major, as long as you meet the general K-State admissions requirements.
Students may declare the CATS minor or secondary major at any point in their undergraduate career by visiting the CATS program office in 202 Eisenhower Hall and speaking to the program director.

Any undergraduate or graduate student in good standing at K-State may enroll in the Conflict Resolution certificate program.

For undergraduate students, complete the secondary major/certificate form (pdf).

For graduate students, complete the certificate program plan form (pdf) in consultation with your major professor and the Director of the Conflict Resolution program.

Undergraduate and graduate students who are not admitted to a degree program may be admitted to the certificate program upon approval by the program director and the dean of the Graduate School (for graduate certificate) or the dean of the appropriate college (for undergraduate certificate).

The Couple and Family Therapy Program accepts students for Fall admission only. The deadline to be considered for an assistantship is December 1. The final deadline for all applications is January 15. All applicants must meet the K-State Graduate School requirements. A minimum 3.0 GPA in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework is required. Required application materials include: 1. A personal statement. 2. A resume or curriculum vitae. 3. Three letters of recommendation. 4. Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended. 5. A scholarly writing sample. 6. Official GRE test scores (optional for Fall 2025 admission). 7. TOEFL scores for international applicants.

To be admitted to the professional teacher education program, students must have:
• 2.75 overall GPA
• Passed the basic skills test OR have an ACT score of 22 OR an SAT score of 1100
• Completion of 40-45 hours of general education requirements with C or better
• Completion of EDCI 200, 230, and EDSP 324 with B or better
• Successful completion of the Professional Portfolio, which includes philosophy of teaching, resume, and reflections
• Two letters of recommendation from faculty members
• A successful interview

To be admitted to the teacher education program, students must meet the following requirements:

- Complete an online application for admission to the Teacher Education Program.
- Must be admitted to Kansas State University.
- Must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75 from all previous coursework (transfer and K-State).
- Must complete a minimum of 30 credit hours.
- Must complete EDCI 200, EDCI 230, and ENGL 100 with a grade of 'C' or higher.
- Must complete the Professional Dispositions survey.
- Must complete a background check through the College of Education contracted service.

Kansas State University has assured admission criteria for freshmen. You will be admitted if you meet ONE of the following criteria: Attain a 3.25 or higher high school GPA OR Achieve an ACT composite score of 21 or higher OR a SAT ERW+M of 1060 or higher. If you don't meet the assured admission criteria, your application will be reviewed on an individual basis. K-State is test-optional, so you can apply without an ACT or SAT score.

K-State has a test-optional admissions process. Assured admissions for Kansas residents: Achieve a 3.25 or higher high school GPA OR Achieve a 21 or higher ACT composite or 1060 or higher SAT ERW+M. Assured admissions for nonresidents: Achieve a 3.25 or higher high school GPA OR Achieve a 21 or higher ACT composite or 1060 or higher SAT ERW+M.

A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution.
A minimum GPA of 3.0.
Successful completion of all prerequisite courses.

Prospective freshmen need to complete the online application, pay the application fee, and submit their official high school transcript. K-State has a test-optional admissions policy and does not require an ACT or SAT score for admission or scholarships.

To be accepted into the Didactic Program in Dietetics (DPD), students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher on a minimum of 30 hours of college credit and have successfully completed FNDH 132 and FNDH 340 with a C or better.

Must be a high school graduate or equivalent. 2.5 minimum high school GPA. Must have a sufficient composite score on the ACT or SAT (or an equivalent score on a test optional admissions review process) as determined by the Kansas Board of Regents. Current K-State students must have a 2.0 minimum GPA.

Students must be admitted to a bachelor's degree program at Kansas State University. A minimum 2.5 GPA is required for admission to the certificate program. Students must maintain a 2.5 GPA in the certificate courses to be awarded the certificate.
Program name: Global Health, Nutrition, and Food Systems

Requirements: Students who wish to pursue the health coaching certificate will need to complete the Secondary Major/Certificate form in KSIS.

Kansas State University has a test-optional admissions process for freshman students. For assured admission, applicants must meet one of the following criteria: a 3.25 or higher unweighted high school GPA, OR an ACT composite score of 21 or higher, OR an SAT ERW+M score of 1060 or higher. Additionally, applicants must complete the precollege curriculum with at least a 2.0 GPA.

Kansas residents who are graduates of an accredited Kansas high school, will be guaranteed admission to Kansas State University if they meet one of the following requirements: Achieve a cumulative high school GPA of 3.25 or higher on a 4.0 scale OR achieve a 21 or higher on the ACT or a 1060 or higher on the SAT. If you do not meet the guaranteed admission requirements, you will be admitted by individual review.

Assured admission for Kansas residents who are graduates of an accredited high school is granted if they meet one of the following: achieve an ACT composite score of 21 or higher OR a SAT ERW+M score of 1060 or higher AND achieve a 2.0 GPA or higher on any college credit taken in high school; OR achieve a 3.25 or higher cumulative high school GPA; OR rank in the top one-third of their high school's graduating class. Assured admission for nonresidents who are graduates of an accredited high school is granted if they meet one of the following: achieve an ACT composite score of 21 or higher OR a SAT ERW+M score of 1060 or higher AND achieve a 2.5 GPA or higher on any college credit taken in high school; OR achieve a 3.25 or higher cumulative high school GPA. Kansas State University also has a test-optional pathway for admission where applications are reviewed individually.

Kansas State University has assured admission requirements for freshman applicants. You will be admitted if you meet the following requirements:

Achieve one of the following:
- High school GPA of 3.25 or higher
- ACT composite score of 21 or higher or SAT ERW+M score of 1060 or higher

AND, if applicable, achieve a 2.0 GPA or higher on all college credit taken in high school.

Test-optional pathway: Applicants can be admitted without test scores if they have a 3.25 or higher GPA.

To be admitted to Kansas State University, you are expected to achieve ONE of the following: Achieve a 3.25 or higher GPA OR Score a 21 or higher on the ACT or a 1060 or higher on the SAT. Additionally, all applicants must complete the pre-college curriculum.

All prospective students must apply to K-State through the Office of Recruitment and Admissions. Specific requirements for first-time freshman and transfer students are detailed on their website. Upon admittance to K-State, you may declare Interior Architecture & Product Design as your major.

To be admitted to K-State, you must have a 2.0+ GPA in your high school coursework in addition to one of the following requirements: Graduate from an accredited high school with a 3.25+ GPA OR ACT score of 21+ or SAT of 1060+. AND Achieve a 2.0 GPA or higher on any college credit taken in high school.
